## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Further Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 860, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 99, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 146, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 119]]<|/det|>
Use the list of formulae (MF19) to find \(\sum_{r = 1}^{n}r(r + 2)\) in terms of \(n\), simplifying your answer. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 439, 186, 458]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 428, 761, 470]]<|/det|>
Express \(\frac{1}{r(r + 2)}\) in partial fractions and hence find \(\sum_{r = 1}^{n}\frac{1}{r(r + 2)}\) in terms of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 439, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 608, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\beta^2 \gamma^2 \delta^2 + \alpha^2 \gamma^2 \delta^2 + \alpha^2 \beta^2 \delta^2 + \alpha^2 \beta^2 \gamma^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 545, 186, 564]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 537, 453, 564]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\frac{1}{\alpha^4} + \frac{1}{\beta^4} + \frac{1}{\gamma^4} + \frac{1}{\delta^4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 539, 920, 558]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 752, 108]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) is given by \(\mathbf{M} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & k \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 \\ k & 1 \end{pmatrix}\), where \(k\) is a constant and \(k \neq 0\) or 1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 144, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 724, 133]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{M}\) represents a sequence of two geometrical transformations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 908, 165]]<|/det|>
State the type of each transformation, and make clear the order in which they are applied. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 271, 146, 288]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 269, 658, 288]]<|/det|>
Write \(\mathbf{M}^{-1}\) as the product of two matrices, neither of which is \(\mathbf{I}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 271, 918, 288]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 456, 143, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 915, 476]]<|/det|>
Show that the invariant points of the transformation represented by \(\mathbf{M}\) lie on the line \(y = \frac{k^2}{1 - k} x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 477, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 430, 91]]<|/det|>
The function f is such that \(\operatorname {f}''(x) = \operatorname {f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 636, 123]]<|/det|>
Prove by mathematical induction that, for every positive integer \(n\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 127, 653, 160]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2n - 1}}{\mathrm{d}x^{2n - 1}} \big(x \mathrm{f}(x)\big) = x \mathrm{f}'(x) + (2n - 1) \mathrm{f}(x). \quad [7]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 833, 96]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = a\sec^{2}\theta\), where \(a\) is a positive constant and \(0\leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 107, 144, 126]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 107, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the polar coordinates of the point of intersection of \(C\) with the initial line and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
also with the half-line \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi\) . [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 438, 143, 458]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 438, 653, 458]]<|/det|>
Find the maximum distance of a point of \(C\) from the initial line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 439, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 593, 143, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 593, 798, 612]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the region enclosed by \(C\), the initial line and the half-line \(\theta = \frac{1}{4}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 593, 920, 612]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The lines \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\) have equations \(\mathbf{r} = 2\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{k} + \lambda (\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} + 2\mathbf{k})\) and \(\mathbf{r} = 2\mathbf{j} + 6\mathbf{k} + \mu (\mathbf{i} + 2\mathbf{j} - 2\mathbf{k})\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 828, 140]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) on \(l_{1}\) and the point \(Q\) on \(l_{2}\) are such that \(PQ\) is perpendicular to both \(l_{1}\) and \(l_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 151, 144, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 151, 312, 170]]<|/det|>
Find the length \(PQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 390, 92]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{1}\) contains \(PQ\) and \(l_{1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 390, 123]]<|/det|>
The plane \(\varPi_{2}\) contains \(PQ\) and \(l_{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 135, 144, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 135, 180, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 813, 153]]<|/det|>
Write down an equation of \(\varPi_{1}\), giving your answer in the form \(\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{a} + s\mathbf{b} + t\mathbf{c}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 228, 180, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 228, 769, 246]]<|/det|>
Find an equation of \(\varPi_{2}\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 228, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 262, 917, 280]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 97, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 415, 104]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{x^2 - x}{x + 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 112, 144, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 487, 131]]<|/det|>
Find the equations of the asymptotes of \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 918, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 186, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 395, 593, 414]]<|/det|>
Find the exact coordinates of the stationary points on \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 918, 414]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 682, 89]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\), stating the coordinates of any intersections with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 71, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 472, 143, 491]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 465, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
Sketch the curve with equation \(y = \left|\frac{x^{2} - x}{x + 1}\right|\) and find in exact form the set of values of \(x\) for which

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
\[\left|\frac{x^{2} - x}{x + 1}\right|< 6. \quad [5]\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 72, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
